questions.questionText: Identify the error: 'The team (A) / are playing (B) / very well (C) / today. (D) / No error (E)'
questions.explanation: Error is in part B. 'The team' is a collective noun and takes a singular verb. Correct: 'The team is playing very well today.'

questions.questionText: Identify the error: 'Each of the (A) / students have (B) / submitted their (C) / assignments. (D) / No error (E)'
questions.explanation: Error is in part B. 'Each' takes a singular verb. Correct: 'Each of the students has submitted their assignments.'

questions.questionText: Identify the error: 'I am (A) / knowing him (B) / since (C) / 2010. (D) / No error (E)'
questions.explanation: Error is in part B. 'Know' is a stative verb and doesn't take continuous form. Correct: 'I have known him since 2010.'

questions.questionText: Identify the error: 'She went (A) / to Delhi (B) / since (C) / two days. (D) / No error (E)'
questions.explanation: Error is in part C. Use 'for' with duration. Correct: 'She has been in Delhi for two days.' (Also needs present perfect tense)

questions.questionText: Identify the error: 'She is (A) / good in (B) / mathematics and (C) / science. (D) / No error (E)'
questions.explanation: Error is in part B. The correct preposition is 'good at' (not 'good in') when talking about skills or subjects. Correct: 'She is good at mathematics and science.'

questions.questionText: Identify the error: 'I saw (A) / a elephant (B) / in the (C) / zoo yesterday. (D) / No error (E)'
questions.explanation: Error is in part B. Use 'an' before words starting with vowel sounds. Correct: 'I saw an elephant in the zoo yesterday.'

questions.questionText: Identify the error: 'He is (A) / an European (B) / by (C) / birth. (D) / No error (E)'
questions.explanation: Error is in part B. 'European' starts with a consonant sound 'yu', so we use 'a'. Correct: 'He is a European by birth.'

questions.questionText: Identify the error: 'One of the (A) / best student (B) / in the class (C) / is absent today. (D) / No error (E)'
questions.explanation: Error is in part B. After 'one of the', we use a plural noun. Correct: 'One of the best students in the class is absent today.'

questions.questionText: Improve the underlined part: 'He is senior than me in the office.'
questions.explanation: The correct expression is 'senior to' (not 'senior than'). We say: senior/junior/superior/inferior TO someone.

questions.questionText: Improve the underlined part: 'Although he is rich but he is not happy.'
questions.explanation: Don't use 'but' with 'although'. Correct: 'Although he is rich, he is not happy.' OR 'He is rich but he is not happy.'

questions.questionText: Improve the underlined part: 'He has went to Delhi yesterday.'
questions.explanation: 'Yesterday' indicates a specific past time, so we use simple past tense. Correct: 'He went to Delhi yesterday.'

questions.questionText: Improve the underlined part: 'Please return back the book tomorrow.'
questions.explanation: 'Return' already means 'go back', so 'back' is redundant. Correct: 'Please return the book tomorrow.'

questions.questionText: Improve the underlined part: 'She is more prettier than her sister.'
questions.explanation: Don't use 'more' with '-er' form. Correct: 'She is prettier than her sister.'

questions.questionText: Replace the phrase: 'He made a mistake in the exam and he had to give the exam again.'
questions.explanation: The correct collocation is 'take an exam' (not 'give an exam'). We say: take a test, take an exam, appear for an exam.

questions.questionText: Replace the phrase: 'She told a mistake in her calculation.'
questions.explanation: The correct collocation is 'make a mistake' (not 'do' or 'tell'). We say: make a mistake, make an error.

questions.questionText: Replace the phrase: 'According with the rules, entry is restricted.'
questions.explanation: The correct prepositional phrase is 'according to' (not 'according with'). Correct: 'According to the rules, entry is restricted.'

questions.questionText: Replace the phrase: 'Despite of the difficulties, he succeeded.'
questions.explanation: 'Despite' is followed directly by a noun, not by 'of'. Correct: 'Despite the difficulties' OR 'In spite of the difficulties'.

questions.questionText: Identify the error: 'Mathematics (A) / are (B) / a difficult (C) / subject. (D) / No error (E)'
questions.explanation: Error is in part B. 'Mathematics' is singular despite its plural form. Correct: 'Mathematics is a difficult subject.'
